page.title: 01TUNSTALL FOREST IN SUFFOLK
page.content: Apart from the meadows alongside Butley River, the soil here is sandy. Wantisden Heath was heathland until the Second World War, after which the introduction of irrigation enabled it to be ploughed and crops grown, especially carrots and beans. Much of the area is divided by deciduous trees, particularly birch and sweet chestnut. Tunstall Common remains heathland, with heather, gorse and broom. There are outcrops of pliocene deposits, known as coralline crag. The church towers at Chillesford and Wantisden are built of this uncommon material. There is a Baptist chapel at Tunstall Common. Chillesford has about 150 inhabitants, largely working on farms, in forestry or retired. Wantisden includes pheasants, partridges, fallow deer and squirrels. There is a herd of red deer in an
